titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Yale Divinity School Faculty Writings and Publications
Yale Divinity School Faculty Writings and Publications
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:16

did.unittitle: Yale Divinity School Faculty Writings and Publications
did.abstract: This collection contains article-length publications and unpublished papers by Yale faculty, primarily from the Divinity School. These writings have been gathered into the collection in order to provide a consolidated repository for the works of Yale Divinity School faculty, past and present. This is not a comprehensive collection but rather consists of writings that have been given to the library by current or past Yale faculty members.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded in 1701, Yale College was a place "wherein Youth through the blessing of Almighty God may be fitted for Publick employment both in Church and Civil State." In 1822 the Divinity School became a separate school within the University and now is one of eleven graduate and professional schools, which, with the College, comprise Yale University. Yale University Divinity School provides three degree programs: the Master of Divinity, the Master of Arts in Religion, and the Master of Sacred Theology.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains article-length publications and unpublished papers by Yale faculty, primarily from the Divinity School. These writings have been gathered into the collection in order to provide a consolidated repository for the works of Yale Divinity School faculty, past and present. This is not a comprehensive collection but rather consists of writings that have been given to the library by current or past Yale faculty members. Booklength writings by faculty members are included in the Library's regular cataloged collection.

The collection does not contain writings of individuals for whom we have separate personal papers collections. These include: Ahlstrom (Sydney) Papers:(RG 83) Bainton (Roland) Papers: (RG 75) Brown (Charles Reynolds) Papers: (RG 37) Burrows (Millar) Papers: (RG 71) Daggett (Oliver Ellsworth) Papers: (RG114) Davies (Henry) Papers: (RG85) Dittes (James E.) Papers: (RG 174) Fitch (Eleazar) Papers: (RG 93) Forman (Charles) Papers: (RG110) Frei (Hans) Papers: (RG 76) Holmer (Paul) Papers: (RG 195) Keck (Leander E.) Papers: (RG 256) Latourette (Kenneth Scott) Papers: (RG 3) Lindbeck (George) Papers: (RG 172) Macintosh (Douglas Clyde) Papers:(RG 50) McGee Street (Lee) Papers: (RG 229) Miller (Randolph Crump) Papers: (RG 173) Morris (Raymond) Papers: (RG 80) Pope (Liston) Papers: (RG 49) Pope (Marvin) Papers: (RG 135) Porter (Frank Chamberlin) Papers: (RG 119) Sanders (Frank Knight) Papers: (RG 122) Shedd (Clarence Prouty) Papers: (RG 35) Slie (Samuel) Papers: (RG 111) Tweedy (Henry Hallam) Papers: (RG 131) Veith (Paul H. ) Papers: (RG 59) Walker (Williston) Papers: (RG 51) Wright (Henry Burt) Papers: (RG 40)

In addition, the following faculty members have more substantial collections in Record Group No. 30, Miscellaneous Personal Papers Collection: John Clark Archer Benjamin W. Bacon John A. Bollier Nils A. Dahl George Park Fisher Samuel Harris Hugh Hartshorne Paul Schubert George Barker Stevens Charles Cutler Torrey
